subject: Re: [junit] How to test console output?

messageBody:
>So said Brett Neumeier on 2003-07-22 --------------------
>On Tue, 2003-07-22 at 14:02, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>> >So said jxingtang on 2003-07-22 --------------------
>> >I do not know whether this is a duplicated question. I have a program
>> >with large number of console output from different source. Basically,
>> >I am using System.out.println(...). How could I verify those outputs
>> >are correct? Thanks!
>>
>> 1. Don't use System.out in your application directly. Your application
>> components should accept a PrintWriter as a parameter somewhere.
>> 2. In your tests, substitute a PrintWriter wrapping a StringWriter in
>> place of System.out. This is easy to verify.
>
>I agree with both of J. B.'s points above. However, at some points in
>the past I have been obligated to use class libraries that write to
>System.out, and which I cannot change. So, to test code that uses these
>libraries, I've found that I get a lot of mileage out of creating a
>little "ConsoleTester" helper class, which appears below. The basic
>idea is, in my unit test I create a ConsoleTester, then exercise the
>code I want to test, then get the output that was written to System.out
>from the ConsoleTester and make assertions about it.
>
>Again, please do not misunderstand: I don't like this approach. In my
>own code, I do not write to System.out, and I recommend that others
>avoid doing so as well.

<snip-code />

This looks good, although I have to question the use of a finalizer. Does that really work? I would think that your test has to call an explicit "put the streams back the way they were" method. Relying on finalize() is generally not a good thing.

Take care.
